1481310986640363521.text: Here comes the "Very Modern Data Stack" according to  @DSJayatillake.  Great outline of a vision for Ruby Labs' future data stack.   https://t.co/fdruuCZSBa. https://t.co/MJMwl7uHVm

1481310989257621510.text: I could see quality/monitoring (@Bigeyedata, @montecarlodata, @datafoldcom), data catalog (@Stemma_ai, @MetaphorData, @SecodaHQ), metrics (@transformio) and Reverse ETL (@HightouchData, @getcensus).

1481310990343946242.text: I'd probably also put @dagsterio, @PrefectIO, or @MetaflowOSS over @ApacheAirflow for orchestration if we're going to call this a very modern data stack.

1481305718959403015.text: @matsonj @JoshGhalgh @_kulte Nice.  It does illustrate the general problem though.  It gets even more acute when the line between infra, policies, and assets isn't clean. For instance, what's the best way to manage warehouses/users/roles in Snowflake.

1481073152058867712.text: @_kulte I probably should have said, "if I remove some task that generates a data asset (e.g. table), who is responsible for deleting the asset."  The point is that infrastructure-as-code operates via reconciliation, whereas data engineering today operates on tasks and flows.

1471934018031538177.text: One of the coolest things about @continual_ai's declarative approach to ML is how well it fits with @getdbt. But declarative ML is also the right foundation to bring analysts, data engineers, analytics engineers, and data scientists onto a shared platform for operational AI.

1471934019767992322.text: A shared platform for operational AI is imperative for AI/ML to become pervasive.  Pipeline-centric or notebook-centric ML platforms are a fragile foundation to accomplish this task.  Sure you can build visual pipeline builders, but is that really the right approach?

1471934020808155138.text: Stay tuned in 2022 for what we have in store to bring everybody onto one shared workflow.  Our bet is the future is declarative and data-first with end-to-end automation that supports the continual lifecycle of production AI/ML.

FWIW, we're trying at @continual_ai by supporting environments (dev, prod) and making everything a declarative configuration change in UI or code.

1458561127319625731.text: ML/AI is drowning in complexity.  The status quo of K8s + bespoke models + pipeline jungles + experiment trackers + deployment platforms + monitoring platforms imposes tremendous costs.  The ecosystem needs a deep rethink. Here's why.

1459025586861473794.text: @BradPorter_ I should qualify that I'm talking AI consumers not AI vendors here.   Obviously building 1 and 2 will require tons of data, compute and expertise.  I'm also fine with declarative data-first approaches if in-house data is really needed to fine tune.

1458687200913096709.text: @mlauber71 @JagersbergKnut @knime Iâ€™m not a fan of visual DAG tools.  They are a different interface but the same problematic level of abstraction. They also have a lot of downsides in production.

1458649753978167300.text: @iced_soy_latte It will happen in stages. OpenAI style APIs are already starting to completely change the game.  We are in the first inning but the next 5 years will see an explosion in few shot APIs. Zero MLOps infra or team is just too compelling to ignore if it works.

1458646600742363136.text: @kylewadegrove I think you get 10x if you think of the full operational lifecycle.  Personalization and forecasting are use cases with high operation burden today but can made trivial with right dsl.  Data intensive vision is harder but will be data first workflow long term.

1458561132461920262.text: Finally, the traditional MLOps stack will persist in pockets as the escape hatch. But better tools will bring at most a 2X simplification here.  Over time even these use cases will shift to higher level abstractions that reduce complexity and empower everybody to do more faster.

1458561133678268423.text: The startups I'm watching that promise a 10X+ simplification include @OpenAI, @CohereAI, @SnorkelAI, and, of course my biased favorite, @continual_ai.  But we need many more!

1458552182614081540.text: @PogrebnyakE @hugobowne It embraced SQL over MapReduce (e.g. Hive) and then got replaced by cloud data warehouses (e.g Snowflake).  The same pattern will happen to most AI/ML use cases although the right abstractions are less obvious.

1458148735947456514.text: Another great addition to the modern metadata ecosystem.
